High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 06 February 2026 and throughout the weekend. River levels are rising at the Fosseway, Brokenborough and Great Somerford gauges in response to overnight rainfall. The levels at the Dauntsey gauge are currently stable. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End6at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. Further rainfall is forecast overnight tonight and on Sunday and river levels may rise further in response. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further alerts and warnings if required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 07 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: High river levels are expected to cause flooding on 6th February 2026. Further rainfall is forecast today and tomorrow, and river levels will remain high. During periods of high tide, the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes have been put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Refer to Local Authority website for road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 7th February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: The Rivers Yeo, Cam and Wriggle all responded to the rainfall overnight but have peaked and now falling. However, the river level at Sherborne Lake remains high and the risk of flooding of nearby low lying land continues. Showers are forecast for today, Friday 6th February, with a band of rain expected overnight. Further showers are forecast over the weekend and into Monday. All rivers are expected to rise early Saturday morning following the rainfall. Particular locations at risk include around the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing blockages from debris screens.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and be aware of local water levels and weather conditions.  This message will be updated by 1pm on 7 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: High river levels today, 06 February 2026 may lead to flooding. This information is correct as of 3:45pm on Friday 06 February 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 21cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has up to 11cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse. High river levels on Friday 06/02/26 may lead to flooding.

Although unlikely, another 10mm of rain is could be possible on Friday evening through to Saturday afternoon.

Only isolated showers are forecast on Friday afternoon. River levels are a little higher than normal in Crowhurst, but falling, and minor flood impacts affecting fields should ease. Minor flooding impacts could remain near Bexhill Road Recreation ground. River levels and flood risk should continue to fall on Friday night, but if rain does affect East Sussex on Saturday morning, then river levels could rise through to Saturday afternoon. More significant rain is forecast on Monday and Tuesday. More flood impacts could be possible next week.

We are closely monitoring the situation .

Consider activating any flood protection products you may have Install flood protection products in Crowhurst.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 07/02/2026

The River Parrett and River Isle have peaked following the rainfall overnight and are starting to fall. However, we expect a further rise early Saturday morning, 7 February, and flooding is possible. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Isle, River Parrett , with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur. Showers are forecast for today, Friday 6 February, with a band of rain expected overnight. Further showers are forecast over the weekend and into Monday. Catchments are saturated and rivers remain very responsive to rainfall. We continue to monitor the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 7 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level has risen to 8.92m and the drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.49m and stable. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. We will operate the River Sowy (Parrett Relief Channel) as conditions allow. Showers are forecast for today, Friday 6th February, with a band of rain expected overnight. Further showers are forecast over the weekend and into Monday. Catchments are saturated and rivers are very responsive to the forecast rainfall. We continue to monitor the situation closely, and check flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on Saturday 07 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.69m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.70m and slowly rising. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Showers are forecast for today, with a band of rain expected overnight. Further showers are forecast over the weekend and into Monday. Catchments are saturated and rivers are expected to be very responsive to the forecast rainfall. We continue to monitor the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 7 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Saturday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 07 February 2026 , as further rain (up to 20mm) is forecast tomorrow. 
Following the recent wet weather, river levels remain high. If as much rain falls as forecast, flooding could affect the recreation ground at Fleming Park, and the river will be very high at Kingfisher Road. Surface water flooding in roads affecting Chandlers Ford and at Stoneham Way from Chestnut Way to the M27 is also possible. Following light showers (7mm) on Sunday (08/02/26), further rainfall is forecast for Monday and Tuesday. If this rain is realised the river will respond again. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions . Report blockages to our hotline 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 08 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Saturday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 07 February 2026 , as up to 20mm of rainfall is forecast. 
If as much rain falls as forecast, flooding could affect land and roads, including Burley Road, Brockenhurst. The river will be bank full as it flows through Martin’s Road and Balmer Lawn Road and may cause garden flooding at Balmer Lawn Road. In Lymington itself, the river will rise over throughout Saturday. Following light showers (up to 7mm) on Sunday (08/02/26) further rainfall is forecast for Monday (09/02/26) and Tuesday (10/02/26). If this impacts the catchment, river levels are likely to rise and remain high until Wednesday (11/02/26). 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Avoid driving through watersplash areas in Brockenhurst. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 08 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.69m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.70m and slowly rising. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 remains closed. For the latest levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Showers are forecast for today, with a band of rain expected overnight. Further showers are forecast over the weekend and into Monday. Catchments are saturated and rivers are expected to be very responsive to the forecast rainfall.  We are monitoring the situation closely and checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 7 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

Minor flooding could affect fields, roads, and possibly gardens of isolated properties between Coolham and Henfield. items.message:
Groundwater levels in the Salisbury Plain have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. Levels are forecast to continue to rise throughout the week. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 9 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 06 February 2026 . 
Areas most at risk are around the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.   We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 07 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the South Wiltshire Downs - The Dene
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 2 February 2026 onwards. 
Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Hindon. The groundwater level at the Terraces borehole has risen to 118.61m, and is expected to continue to rise throughout this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. Roads may be impassable due to flood water, do not drive through floodwater.
This message will be updated by 10:45AM on 9 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels may lead to flooding. 

River levels are high on parts of the River Coln. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 06 Feb 2026, especially in the Fossebridge area. Further rain is forecast for today, overnight and into Saturday. We expect levels to remain high over the coming days. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels. 

This message will be updated by 12:00 on 07 Feb 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 07/02/2026 because of a very wet start to 2026. 
Today (05/02/2026), it is possible that up to 30mm of rain could be recorded in Hampshire. If this affects the area, a small number of properties in Preston Candover and Old Alresford could experience cellar flooding from Saturday 07/02/2026. Flooding could affect the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. Lighter rain is forecast from Friday 06/02/2026 to Monday 09/02/2026. Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford will continue rising slowly into next week. Isolated properties in Old Alresford could possibly experience internal ground floor flooding in the next 2 weeks. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 12 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High tides on Saturday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 2 hours either side of Saturday's early morning tide and early afternoon tide on 07/02/2026. 
For the tide at 02:30, the weather increases tide table values by 0.43m. Total forecast tide is 5.01 metres Chart Datum (2.28 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Strong Southerly Force 5 wind. For the tide at 14:45, the tide is forecast to be 23 cm lower (2.05 mAOD). The shingle beach at Eastoke Corner has been impacted by high energy waves. Water could push further up the beach than normal. Property at Eastoke corner, near the nature reserve, and Southwood Road may flood. Overtopping of splash walls along the beach front may flood gardens. Beach huts at West Beach, near the Inn on The Beach may be affected. 
We are closely monitoring the situation  
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have Avoid South Hayling seafront. Shingle can be thrown by wind and waves. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 07 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mansbridge and Woodmill on the River Itchen
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Saturday. 
Flooding is expected on 07 February 2026 because of the combination of rain and high tide.   
The next high tide is forecast at 02:15 and 04:10 on Saturday morning (07/02/2026). The water level is expected to be 4.89 metres Chart Datum (2.15 mAOD). Flooding will affect the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Water may be forced up through the floor of the Pub. Riverside Park will also be flooded. Levels may also be very high around Gaters Mill. Saturday's tide at 14:20 is forecast to be 25cm lower. However, further rainfall (20mm) is expected Saturday (07/02/26), so river levels will remain high. Flooding impacts will remain similar. 
We are checking rivers for blockages and liaising with Southampton City Council on operation of Woodmill. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have including defences around the White Swan pub. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 07 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 06 February 2026 , as 22mm of rain has fallen in the last 24 hours. 
This is a modest amount of rainfall but follows recent wet weather. Flooding could affect Bishopstoke Road Playing Fields and possibly some gardens in Bishopstoke. Water may also affect the top of Duttons Lane and Withy Meadows, Eastleigh. Further rainfall (up to 15mm) is forecast from this evening (06/02/26) until Saturday afternoon (07/02/26). There is potential for more rain on Monday (09/02/26) and Tuesday (10/02/26). The river will remain responsive to any further rain that it receives. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and managing sluices at Bishopstoke and Stoke Lock. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 08 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels at Lisle Street Gauge may rise rapidly due to the reactive nature of the catchment in response to heavy rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. Areas most at risk are properties at Prince William Way, Prince William Road, Jubilee Drive, Monarch Way, Waldron Court, Belton Road West Extension, Lisle Street and Derby Road near Burleigh Brook. If levels continue to rise, properties at Bottleacre Lane, Belton Road near Bottleacre Lane, Staveley Court, Meadow Avenue, Waterside Close and surrounding areas are at risk. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Start acting on your flood plan if you have one and do not walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 03:00 AM on 07 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message:

items.message: Considerable floodwater remains on the Somerset Levels and Moors. Upstream catchments are saturated and are very responsive to rainfall. Areas most at risk include locations near the River Yeo, River Parrett and River Cary, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of runway. items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Pimperne Brook
items.message: This is a Groundwater Flood Warning Update. Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Pimperne Brook at Pimperne. The groundwater level at Iwerne Hill Farm borehole is 115.23m, and is expected to remain high over the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. Residents should continue to keep any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers deployed. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk. Please take care and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 11 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.69m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst above 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.70m and slowly rising. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 is closed. For road closure information refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates. Pumping continues at Northmoor and Saltmoor and we have additional mobile pumps at both stations. The River Tone level remains high and pumping at Currymoor will commence when river levels allow. The River Sowy relief channel will be operated when conditions allow. Showers are forecast for today, with a band of rain expected overnight. Further showers are forecast over the weekend and into Monday. Catchments are saturated and rivers are very responsive to rainfall. We are monitoring the situation closely and checking floodbanks and spillways. Please do not walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 7 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Brain through Braintree, to and including Witham
items.message:
Rising river levels are expected to cause flooding overnight. 
Flooding is expected from overnight on 06 February 2026 following rainfall today.   
Areas most at risk are properties at The Waterings, and St. Johns Avenue in Braintree, and Bridge Street and Guithavon Valley in Witham. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . Further rainfall is forecast today. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 07 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message: The River Yeo level has risen to 8.92m and the drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.49m and stable. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. We will operate the River Sowy (Parrett Relief Channel) as conditions allow. Showers are forecast for today, Friday 6th February, with a band of rain expected overnight. Further showers are forecast over the weekend and into Monday. Catchments are saturated and rivers are very responsive to the forecast rainfall. We continue to monitor the situation closely, and check flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on Saturday 07 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message: Water levels in Saltmoor and Northmoor remain high today, Friday 6 February. The drain level at Northmoor pumping station is 3.83m and at Northmoor Main Drain Remote is 4.47m.  The level in Currymoor is stable, though still very high. Athelney spillway continues to run into Saltmoor and Northmoor. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Works are ongoing to improve the flow along Northmoor Main Drain to maximise pumping into the Parrett. The River Tone level remains too high to pump at Currymoor but will commence when river levels allow. The River Sowy (Parrett Relief Channel) will operate when conditions allow. Showers are forecast for today, with a band of rain expected overnight. Further showers are forecast over the weekend and into Monday. Catchments are saturated and rivers are very responsive to rainfall. We are monitoring the situation closely and checking floodbanks and spillways. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 1pm on 7 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Groundwater is high, and slowly rising again at the Houndean Bottom borehole. Only showers or small amounts of rain are forecast Friday to Sunday. Groundwater is expected to remain high. Groundwater rise at Houndean Bottom borehole should pause around 09/02/2026. There is uncertainty in the forecast, but currently rain is predicted Monday and Tuesday (10/02/2026), with unsettled weather continuing the rest of next week too. From 10/02/2026 springs will appear, water will affect fields, the recreation ground, and a small number of cellars in Denton. If we get the maximum rain Monday and Tuesday, then a small amount of water may appear on Denton Road, may flow towards Vicarage Close and affect areas near the three ponds in South Heighton. Flood risk will remain until March. Take care on roads that flood (Denton Road). Ensure pumps work. We will monitor, and update this message by 18:00 10/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Groundwater is high and slowly rising. Another 10mm of rain is forecast for Friday night into Saturday, followed by showers this weekend. Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Springs will appear, water will be in fields, and water will flow down roads, including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden, between Cooks Lane and Barley Mow in Walderton, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane. Groundwater will also affect a small number of cellars in Stoughton and Walderton. Groundwater rise at Compton borehole should pause around 11/02/2026. However, with the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Monday and Tuesday, it is possible that groundwater will rise until 15/02/2026. Take care on roads that flood (Stoughton, Walderton). Ensure pumps work. We will monitor, and update this message by 18:00 10/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Groundwater is high and slowly rising. Groundwater is at the very top of our borehole in East Dean, and 1m below the surface at Chilgrove. Another 10mm of rain is forecast for Friday night into Saturday, followed by showers this weekend. Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Springs will appear, water will be in fields, small amounts of water will flow down roads, groundwater will affect the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean, and may start to appear in a small number of basements. Groundwater rise at Chilgrove borehole should pause around 11/02/2026, but will continue at East Dean borehole until at least the last week of February. However, with the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Monday and Tuesday, it is possible that groundwater will rise in East Dean until March. Take care on roads that flood (Chilgrove, West Dean, Singleton, East Dean). Ensure pumps work. We will update this message by 18:00 10/02/2026.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 06 February 2026 , as 25mm of rain fell in the last 48 hours. 
This is a modest amount but follows recent wet weather. Flooding is affecting low lying land and Horsebridge Road, Broughton, and will be close to property at Duck’s Lane, Church Street and The Square at Nether Wallop, where it may flood gardens. Tomorrow (07/02/26) up to 20mm of rainfall is forecast. If this is realised the river will respond again. Following light showers (7mm) on Sunday (08/02/26), further rainfall is forecast for Monday (09/02/26) and Tuesday (10/02/26). River levels will remain higher than normal, and flood risk will continue into next week. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 08 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible . Over a month's rain (69mm) has fallen in the last week. 
We expect the Idsworth Lavant to be flowing. Pumps which may prevent water from entering property may be required. Surface water may flood property during heavier rain events. Further rain (up to 20mm) is forecast on Thursday (05/02/2026). Lighter rain is forecast from Friday (06/02/2026) to Sunday (08/02/2026). If heavy rain affects the area, then groundwater levels will rise into next week. From this weekend, road flooding, including Chalton Road in Finchdean, could become deep in all villages. Cellar flooding could occur in Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 11 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible as a lot of rain (45mm) has fallen in the last week. 
Currently, groundwater levels in Kings Somborne are stable around 10cm below where we would expect flooding to begin affecting cellars in a small number of properties along Winchester Road, central King's Somborne and in Little Somborne. Today (05/02/2026), up to 30mm of rain is forecast to affect Hampshire. From Friday (06/02/2026) to Monday (09/02/2026), lighter rain is forecast with another 30mm possible across these 4 days. If heavy rain affects Kings Somborne and Little Somborne, the level will begin rising again and flooding impacts could begin within the next week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 12 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Saturday. 
Flooding is expected on 07 February 2026 . A lot of rain fell Friday, and more is forecast Saturday.   
River levels remain high, and flooding is continuing to affect Titchfield Hill with very high water levels at Titchfield Mill, Bridge Cottage and at the Tanneries Industrial Estate. More rain (20mm) is forecast Friday night and throughout Saturday (07/02/2026). Following light showers (7mm) on Sunday, further rain is forecast for Monday and Tuesday. Any intense rainfall events are likely to cause surface water flooding in Titchfield High Street. Ensure any flood protection products you have are activated. The risk of flooding will continue until at least Wednesday (11/02/2026). 
We are checking rivers for blockages . 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses . 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 07 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Sandown, Brading and Bembridge on the Eastern Yar
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Saturday. 
Flooding is expected on 07 February 2026 following 20mm of rain in the last 24 hours.   
Flooding is affecting Moreton Common and Golf Links roads. Fort Holiday Park and Sandown Sewage works could flood as ditches struggle to drain to the main river. Impacts are also possible at Nicholas Close, Brading. Levels are expected to rise again, as up to 20mm of rain is forecast on Saturday 07/02/2026. Following light showers (7mm) on Sunday 08/02/2026, further rain is forecast for Monday and Tuesday. If this is realised, the river will respond again, with river levels and flood risk likely to remain into next week. 
We are checking rivers for blockages and operating Bembridge sluices. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have  
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 07 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 06 February 2026 and 07 February 2026 
River levels are high following weeks of rain, but slowly falling following Friday morning's rain. Isolated showers are forecast Friday afternoon, small and brief river rises could be possible. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Saturday morning. River levels will rise again from 07:00 07/02/2026. Perhaps another 5cm. Flooding will continue to affect fields, roads and gardens, including Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane, the Green, and bridges across the river in East Lavant. Water could also affect gardens at The Sadlers in Westhampnett. More rain and isolated property flooding is possible next week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and operating structures in Westhampnett for the Flood Alleviation Scheme. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk Avoid roads that flood (Sheepwash Lane). Report blockages to 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 07 February 2026 or as the situation changes.
